It is named as `MessageRoutingPolicy` in Cpp.
and in python is used as: `                      message_routing_mode=PartitionsRoutingMode.RoundRobinDistribution,`

Here is a detailed define in python:
```
   def create_producer(self, topic,
                        producer_name=None,
                        schema=schema.BytesSchema(),
                        initial_sequence_id=None,
                        send_timeout_millis=30000,
                        compression_type=CompressionType.NONE,
                        max_pending_messages=1000,
                        max_pending_messages_across_partitions=50000,
                        block_if_queue_full=False,
                        batching_enabled=False,
                        batching_max_messages=1000,
                        batching_max_allowed_size_in_bytes=128*1024,
                        batching_max_publish_delay_ms=10,
                        message_routing_mode=PartitionsRoutingMode.RoundRobinDistribution,   < ===
                        properties=None,
                        ):
```

> Usually the executing path is PULSAR_HOME, so the relative paths is based on PULSAR_HOME.

The script sets PULSAR_HOME to be the directory in which pulsar itself is installed; any existing value is ignored.

As an end user, I cannot see why anyone would want to store their *user* data in the *application's* private directory tree; normal users won't even have permission to do so.

If other components need to find each other relative to PULSAR_HOME, then it would be fine to set PULSAR_HOME without changing the working directory; but anything in the code which opens "foo/bar" would then have to change to opening "$PULSAR_HOME/foo/bar"

> Will it work after remove change the working directory?

Apparently not:

```
$ apache-pulsar-2.4.1/bin/pulsar-admin help
2019-11-14 08:15:24,677 main ERROR FileNotFoundException: language=JavaScript, path=./conf/log4j2-scripts/filter.js, actualCharset=UTF-8
2019-11-14 08:15:24,678 main ERROR Null object returned for ScriptFile in Scripts.
Was passed main parameter 'help' but no main parameter was defined
```

That appears to come from here:

```
$ grep -R conf/log4j2-scripts/filter.js .
./conf/log4j2.yaml:      path: ./conf/log4j2-scripts/filter.js
```

And I think I can see another relative path in there:

```
  Properties:
    Property:
      - name: "pulsar.log.dir"
        value: "logs"
```

However, I don't code in Java.  Even if it had worked for me once, that wouldn't prove it would work under all circumstances.

As an end user, all I can say is that it would be helpful for me for the current working directory to be honoured.

Only the developers can say whether changing the working directory to PULSAR_HOME is a necessary part of the implementation, or whether it could be changed easily and safely not to do so.

backward compatibility(for 2.2.0, 2.3.0, 2.40) check is added, please help review this PR.

I wonder if flush() is intended to do with [batching](https://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/concepts-messaging/#batching).

Suppose you enable batching, then:

1. `send_async()` 50 messages
2. do other stuff
3. `flush()`

At the point you do call flush, the batch may or may not have already reached its maximum latency and been sent.  If any messages are still in RAM, presumably flush will send them.  But either way, if flush waits for anything, surely it must wait for *all* messages to be persisted - even if the batch was empty.  If it did nothing when the batch was empty, there would be a race.

Identical problems with Go API. I'm adding this to the same ticket as it may be to do with the underling C++ API.

Code:

```
package main

import (
	"context"
	"fmt"
	"time"

	log "github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go/logutil"
	"github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go/pulsar"
)

const NUM_MESSAGES = 500

var counter = 0

func callback(msg pulsar.ProducerMessage, err error) {
	if err != nil {
		log.Fatal(err)
	}
	counter += 1
}

func main() {
	client, err := pulsar.NewClient(pulsar.ClientOptions{
		URL:       "pulsar://localhost:6650",
		IOThreads: 5,
	})

	if err != nil {
		log.Fatal(err)
	}

	defer client.Close()

	producer, err := client.CreateProducer(pulsar.ProducerOptions{
		Topic: "temp",
	})
	if err != nil {
		log.Fatal(err)
	}

	defer producer.Close()

	ctx := context.Background()

	for i := 0; i < NUM_MESSAGES; i++ {
		producer.SendAsync(ctx, pulsar.ProducerMessage{
			Payload: make([]byte, 1_000_000, 1_000_000),
		}, callback)
	}
	log.Info("Flushing...")
	producer.Flush()
	log.Info("Flushed")
	for counter < NUM_MESSAGES {
		fmt.Printf("Received %d out of %d\n", counter, NUM_MESSAGES)
		time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
	}
	log.Info("I'm done, going to sleep")
	time.Sleep(time.Hour)
}
```

Output:

```
2019/11/14 12:18:40.908 prod-leak.go:51: [info] Flushing...
2019/11/14 12:18:40.908 prod-leak.go:53: [info] Flushed
Received 231 out of 500
Received 245 out of 500
Received 263 out of 500
Received 272 out of 500
Received 292 out of 500
Received 294 out of 500
Received 294 out of 500
Received 294 out of 500
Received 294 out of 500
Received 307 out of 500
Received 331 out of 500
Received 336 out of 500
Received 344 out of 500
Received 354 out of 500
Received 377 out of 500
Received 381 out of 500
Received 402 out of 500
Received 421 out of 500
Received 435 out of 500
Received 455 out of 500
Received 459 out of 500
Received 468 out of 500
Received 472 out of 500
Received 472 out of 500
Received 489 out of 500
Received 496 out of 500
2019/11/14 12:18:43.569 prod-leak.go:58: [info] I'm done, going to sleep
```

Check memory usage:

```
$ ps auxwww | grep prod-leak | grep -v grep
ubuntu   11321  0.0  2.8 1505392 470344 ?      Sl+  12:18   0:01 ./prod-leak
```

Sorry, this was me being dumb.

* C++ API is allocating, then freeing memory
* malloc is not returning it to the system, in case it's needed again; but it can re-use this space

To test this, I changed the program to:

- send 500MB of messages; wait for them all to be delivered
- send another 500MB of messages; wait for them all to be delivered

Results are fine:

```
Sent: 500 messages 500000000 bytes
Results: {'Ok': 500}
   VSZ   RSS COMMAND
619772 401376 python3
Snooze
   VSZ   RSS COMMAND
619772 401376 python3
...
Results: {'Ok': 1000}
   VSZ   RSS COMMAND
592424 374188 python3
Snooze
   VSZ   RSS COMMAND
592424 374188 python3
```

In fact, memory footprint has gone *down* after creating another 500 messages.

Code for reference:

```
from collections import defaultdict
import gc
import os
import pulsar
import subprocess
import time

NUM_MESSAGES = 500
MESSAGE_SIZE = 1_000_000

client = pulsar.Client('pulsar://localhost:6650')

producer = client.create_producer('temp', producer_name='fred')

# Ensure that stdout is flushed on each line
old_print = print
def print(*a, **b):
    old_print(*a, flush=True, **b)

sent = 0
bytes = 0
results = defaultdict(lambda: 0)
def ack(res, msg):
    global sent, bytes
    sent += 1
    bytes += len(msg.data())
    #bytes += len(msg)
    results[str(res)] += 1

for rep in range(2):
    sent = 0
    for i in range(NUM_MESSAGES):
        data = b"x" * MESSAGE_SIZE
        producer.send_async(data, callback=ack)
        #res = producer.send(data)
        #ack(res, data)

    print("Flushing...")
    producer.flush()
    print("Flush complete")
    for i in range(600):
        print("Sent: %d messages %d bytes" % (sent, bytes))
        if sent == NUM_MESSAGES:
            break
        time.sleep(0.1)
    else:
        print("Never got all the messages!")
    print("Results: %r" % dict(results))

    gc.collect()
    subprocess.run(["ps","-eo","vsz,rss,comm","-q",str(os.getpid())])
    print("Snooze")
    time.sleep(1)
    subprocess.run(["ps","-eo","vsz,rss,comm","-q",str(os.getpid())])

producer.close()
client.close()
```

I will open new ticket for flush() though.
